2.31 p.m.

DEVELOPMENT ESTIMATES, 1960



    The Chairman: The Development Estimates-for the convenience of hon. Members I intend taking the totals for each head as they appear in the fourth column of the summary of expenditure on page 468 of Paper Cmd. (New Series) 32 of 1959.

    Head D9 -

    Mr A. P. Rajah (Farrer Park): Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head D9 be reduced by $10 in respect of item (2) of sub-head 1.

    Item (2) of sub-head 1, "Singapore River Project $2,000,000; Subject to Treasury sanction."

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I remember some years ago, a working committee was appointed by the Government to go into the whole question of the Singapore River and what should be done with it, not only from the point of view of the river traffic on it, but also from the sanitary point of view. The Singapore River, as you know, Mr Speaker, passes through the densely populated area of the City and the sanitary exits to most of the premises in this area are into the Singapore River. As far as I can make out, the Singapore River is not only an artery of trade but it also provides an exit for the sanitary facilities of the City. Because of this, the City health authorities were worried about the state of the

Column: 1174

Singapore River. Several approaches had been made to Government from time to time to see that something should be done to the Singapore River. Therefore, I am very glad, Mr Speaker, Sir, to see that some provision has been made in next year's estimates, although I regret to find under the remarks column "Subject to Treasury sanction". This very often means that the scheme might not be carried out. I would like the assurance of the Finance Minister that the scheme is sufficiently well in hand for it to be commenced next year and, should that be the position, that he will give sympathetic approval to this scheme.

    The Minister for Finance (Dr Goh Keng Swee): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Government's main interest in this river project is, of course, from the point of view of trade. As the Member for Farrer Park has said, this proposal was first examined quite some time ago. In fact, a Committee was formed in 1954 to investigate the condition of the river and to make recommendations for its improvement. That Committee went into some detail in the engineering aspects of river improvement. Perhaps I may be permitted to explain briefly what are the improvements envisaged, and what is the Government's attitude towards these improvements.

    The river is important because it is one of the principal arteries of our entrepot trade. Many people may not be aware of the fact that more cargo is discharged through the river than through the wharves of the Singapore Harbour Board, that is if we exclude bunker oil. The traffic up and down the river is impeded in two ways. First, part of the river has been rather heavily silted up, so that at low tide movement of lighters is not possible. Then again at high tide there is not sufficient headway under the bridges, so that again lighter traffic is held up.

    The Committee proposed certain types of alteration. First, to repair or to reconstruct the bridges so that there is sufficient headway at high tide. Then it would be necessary to dredge a channel along the Singapore River so that traffic can proceed at low tide. Once dredging

Column: 1175

operations are commenced, there is every danger that the quays of the river may collapse. Therefore, before the channel of the river is deepened, it will be necessary to strengthen the quays by means of sheet piling. This will be a most costly operation. The original cost is $7� million and the latest estimate is that it will probably be nearer the region of $14 million. The estimated original cost of $14 million has now been increased to some $23 million. Now, it is obvious that there are independent aspects of this work, for instance, the reconstruction of bridges can proceed quite independently of the work of deepening the channel of the river, while repair to the quay side (for instance, attending to the deplorable state of some of the private quays) is again quite independent of any deepening of the channel. But no attempt has so far been made to assess the benefit from each item of this total programme against possible benefits; for instance, if you are to reconstruct the bridges, how many more hours' traffic will that permit? What will be the gain to traders and shippers? And if you are to undertake this extremely expensive business of deepening the channel, how much more will the Singapore River be open to trade, and how fast will ships be able to turn over the cargo and so on and so forth?

    Our Government is now engaged in weighing the benefits to be gained against the items of separate cost so that we can be sure that, if we do embark on this most expensive project, we will get good value for money. Now, if the channel were to be deepened, the advice of the engineers is that the waters of the Singapore River would flow at such a rate that it would eliminate the present malodorous state of the river of which the Member for Farrer Park has complained.

    Mr Rajah: Sir, in view of the explanation by the Hon. the Minister for Finance, may I be given leave to withdraw?

    Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.

    Head D12 -

    Tun Lim Yew Hock (Cairnhill): Mr Speaker, Sir, I move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head Dl2 be reduced by $10 in respect of sub-head 1.

    Sir, this particular provision is a token vote for equipment for new post offices. But I do not see anywhere under this head any provision, be it token or actual, for the building of new post offices. If there are no new post offices to be built, is there any necessity to have a token provision for the equipment for new post offices which are not to be built at all?

    The Deputy Prime Minister (Dr Toh Chin Chye): Mr Speaker, the Postal Department has a programme for the building of nine new post offices. This programme is divided into three phases. Phase (a) was the building of post offices at Thomson Road and Serangoon Garden Estate. This phase was completed in 1958, at the cost of $246,500.

    Phase (b) involves the building of five further post offices at Paya Lebar, the Singapore Harbour Board, Macpherson Road, Kampong Kapor and Killiney Road. Work on the Paya Lebar office was begun in 1958, and provision was made in the 1959 estimates for the work to be completed. Because of limited finances at that time, work on the remaining four items of phase (b) was deferred. No provision for these items was entered in the 1959 estimates and in those estimates, the four items were relegated to a schedule of Public Work projects deferred for consideration in connection with future loan programmes and the general availability of finance. So the new P.A.P. Government has inherited this problem.

    Phase (c) involves the building of two post offices at Simpang Bedok and Farrer Road. In preparing the 1960 estimates, the postal services hope that money could be found for the construction of some, if not all, of the four post offices remaining in phase (b). An application was made for provision to be entered in the Development Estimates. Simultaneously, a proposal was made for $3,400 to purchase equipment necessary to furnish the post offices.

If necessary and when the need arises, Members of the House will be assured that an application for supplementary provision will be made.

    I would add, Mr Speaker, that we in Singapore are fortunate that we have an excellent postal service which can guarantee us that when a letter is despatched it will be delivered, and when a man goes to the post office to send a cable it will be promptly transmitted. And if the Member for Farrer Park had gone-

    Inche Ahmad Jabri(In Malay): Mr Speaker, on the sub-head concerning postal services, we have heard the explanation given by the Deputy Prime Minister and the Government's intentions regarding the postal services. As has been narrated by the Deputy Prime Minister, there are three types of programmes and they all cover only the City area. No mention was made of programmes covering the Southern Islands. It is evident that I have already mentioned many matters concerning the Southern Islands, Mr Speaker, because I am of the opinion that there is room for improvement in the postal services in certain areas there. I find that one of these places is Palau Bukom. On the main Bukom Island there are no postal services. I feel concerned about what has happened previously. I have received complaints and appeals to the effect that the oil company at Pulau Bukom is prepared to provide a building for a post office at the place where the postal staff now only sell stamps. Unfortunately, however, until today I have not heard of any development regarding the company's offer. Therefore, I would like to draw the attention of the Government that it is only proper that a branch or a sub-post office be opened there, which can be of benefit to the residents of the Southern Islands, the majority of whom are found on Bukom Island and to provide them with easy communication with the Singapore mainland. Otherwise, in the absence of such facilities, it will be very difficult for them when they are in need of urgent communication.

Column: 1179



    Dr Toh Chin Chye: Mr Speaker, I will certainly pay attention to what the Member for the Southern Islands has brought up about Pulau Bukom. Of course, he will agree that it is not possible to set up a sub-post office on an island where there are, say, 50 or 100 inhabitants who do not write letters every day.

    Head D13 -

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: Mr Speaker, Sir, I move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head D13 be reduced by $10 in respect of sub-head 3.

    Under this Head D13, Sir, 17 sub-heads have been itemised except sub-head 3. Under this sub-head, what is stated is just "General". Would the Minister be good enough to inform this House what kind of expenditure comes under "General"?

    Dr Toh Chin Chye: Mr Speaker, I can very well understand the anxiety of the Member for Cairnhill about having every item inserted in the Development Estimates. In the 1959 estimates, under "General", the items were a power supply unit, telegraph filters, test equipment, all amounting to $24,550. This year there are several trifling items which the Telecommunications Department wish to purchase, and if you want to insert each and every one of them in the estimates I am afraid it will take up a considerable amount of space. But to assure the Member for Cairnhill, the type of equipment which the Department of Telecommunications will need are aerial multi-couplets to cover maintenance and fog periods on 36 working units, air conditioning plant for expansion of air-conditioning room at the transmitting station, amplifier panels to provide stand-by for 18 v.m. channels, auto alarm for detecting automatically distress signals from ships, D.C. rectifying unit, diesel-electric generating sets, switch-board three-phase telegraph filters. Personally, I have great trust that

Column: 1180

the Acting Director for Telecommunications will use this sum of money to improve the running of his department. I can assure the Member for Cairnhill that there is no other underlying motive behind "General".

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: Sir, I did not insinuate anything at all in my speech that there have been any underhand motives in it. What I asked, as a Member of this House, was for information. As the information has already been given, may I beg leave to withdraw?

    That the sum to be allocated for Head Dl3 be reduced by $10 in respect of sub-head 10.

    Dr Toh Chin Chye: Mr Speaker, it is part of the revote. The reason why the full amount has not been entered is because the Ministry of Finance intends to set up a committee of supply, consisting of experts, to investigate into the claims made by other Ministries. It is important that laymen should at least be fully satisfied that technical claims made by technical departments are fully justified. The Civil Aviation Department relies heavily on Telecommunications for its proper operations. These services are provided by the Telecommunications Department.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: Mr Speaker, Sir, I move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head D14 be reduced by $10 in respect of sub-head 1.

    I would like the Minister for National Development to inform us when the Housing Authority will be created and what plans he has to use this $25 million for the building of low-cost housing which we have read about so much; how many units there will be; and where they will be situated.

    Mr Rajah: Mr Speaker, Sir, some few months ago the Minister for National Development announced in the Press that he had a comprehensive programme for housing over the next five years which would total about $415 million, and that this $415 million would be spread over the five years of the P.A.P. being in power. Assuming that the report in the Press is correct, Mr Speaker, Sir, I see that the provision for next year's housing is only $25 million - not even a fifth of the $415 million which the Minister said would be expended over the five years. I further find that this $25 million is also subject to Treasury sanction. It rather gives me the impression that plans have not been finalised to the extent that the Treasury has approved of them. Could the Minister for National Development also inform the House whether this $25 million includes the cost of sites or whether it merely includes the cost of buildings themselves? Could the Minister also tell the House how many housing units it is intended to build out of this $25 million, and how much the cost per unit would be?

    Mr Thio Chan Bee: Mr Speaker, Sir, I presume that most of the money allocated for next year would be spent on providing low-cost housing for the poorer sections of the population. At the same time, we know that the rate of population increase is such that, in order to cope with the annual increase, about 10,000 housing units a year should be provided. Together with the back-log and in order to cope with the situation, we should provide, say, 15,000 housing units yearly for the next five years. We know that the maximum building capacity so far achieved by the

Column: 1182

S.I.T. is about 4,000 to 5,000 housing units.

    Even with the best will and intention in the world, the S.I.T. or the new Housing Authority might be able to provide, say, 8,000 units. I am speaking on behalf of those families wanting accommodation, who are not provided by the S.I.T. We know there are thousands of families who have been queueing up and have not been able to become eligible because of the points system. Unless a family has at least five points, it is not eligible. So only large families are eligible. A newly-married couple or a couple with one child or two children cannot apply for an S.I.T. house. If the S.I.T. cannot provide houses for such people, then they have to turn to private enterprise. Therefore, Sir, I hope that the Government will give every encouragement to private enterprise to provide housing for those who are not provided by the Housing Authority. I hope an assurance will be given by the Government at this time.

    The Minister for National Development (Mr Ong Eng Guan): Mr Speaker, when the P.A.P. became the Government, we were faced with problems which would take some time to resolve. We found, when we opened the cash till, that most of the money which the people had given to the care of the old Government had disappeared. As the Deputy Prime Minister said one day, Christmas Island was sold; luckily the people opened their eyes, or otherwise this Island of Singapore would also be sold.

    There are many problems to be solved by the new Government. Not only was there a shortage of money, not only were our reserves spent in a carefree manner, but there were also other problems which the other governments - the colonial government and the Lim Yew Hock Government - had left to the P.A.P. Government to solve: for instance, as the Member for Tanglin has said just now, a back-log of houses to be built, a shortage of accommodation which for the past ten years the colonial administration had never tried to solve, and which had been entrusted to us. In a word, Mr Speaker, the P.A.P. Government has had to carry the baby.

Column: 1183



    We do agree with the Member for Tanglin that, in order to cope with the back-log which the colonial government had left us to solve, we need to build an average of 17,500 units a year. We understand that fact. But, Mr Speaker, in the present economic position in Singapore, we cannot do much better than what our Minister for Finance has done, to allocate $25 million for housing. There are many competing demands on the restricted financial resources available to the P.A.P. Government. Schools have not been adequately supplied and, as the Minister for Education mentioned yesterday, delinquency is high and many children have not been able to go to schools. There is a shortage of hospitals for the needy; a shortage of social services for the sick and the needy. Because of these competing demands, the Government has done its very best by allocating the sum of $25 million to one requirement alone, that is housing.

    Mr Speaker, this is the first year of the P.A.P. Government. In the first year of the Tun Lim Yew Hock Government, they only allocated $9 million for housing. $9 million versus $25 million! Of course, every sector of economic activity in this Island wants more money. We want $50 million for schools, $50 million for hospitals, $50 million for social service, etc, etc. But it is not possible to get all the money and it is the task of the Government to allocate the money judiciously and wisely so that we will do our best with the limited funds at our disposal.

    Mr Speaker, we are doing our very best as far as housing is concerned, with our limited funds. We have reorganised the S.I.T. almost completely. We have sacked or ousted the expatriate architects who had been guilty of irregularities. We forced them to quit or else action would be taken against them. We did not want to waste time by sending them to the Court because, in some cases, it would be just a waste of time. For instance, in the course of two weeks, we found that more than 20 to 30 items of irregularities had been charged against one architect. And to most of these items, he could not give a satisfactory answer. There were six

Column: 1184

expatriate architects and we took action to replace them with six local architects.

    Mr Speaker, there are some people still at large in this country who have no confidence in the ability of our people to put up plans for housing, hospitals, and to run this country. But, Mr Speaker, we have confidence in our own people and in our own professional men. As soon as we reorganised the S.I.T. from August onwards and took over full control, within the course of one month, we terminated the services of 30 expatriates out of 35, leaving a few engineers who have experience and who at the moment are a bit difficult to replace. But for the other sectors - the administration, the management and the architects - we have replaced them completely with local professional men. Mr Speaker, we have 100 per cent confidence in our local people.

3.15 p.m.

    In conjunction with housing, we need to have a good Planning Committee in the S.I.T. because the two are joined up - housing requires good planning - and it is important that there should be an honest and efficient Planning Department in the S.I.T. both for public housing and, as the Member for Tanglin says, for private housing. The corruption and filth in the Planning Department in the old S.I.T. has been mentioned many times in this House. As soon as we took over control in August and as soon as action was taken to investigate the Planning Committee, the most important person against whom many allegations had been made, scooted. As soon as he left the country, he submitted a letter of resignation. We have now thoroughly reorganised the Planning Section. Previously - and this is for the information of the Member for Tanglin - local architectural firms found it very, very difficult to get their plans expedited. But European architectural firms could build installations worth $10 million or even small installations, first, and then after a few years submit their plans for confirmation. Mr Speaker, we have rectified all these abuses and irregularities of the past. In the case of local firms, we now treat them fairly and on an equal footing with foreign firms. We have even gone

Column: 1185

one step further. And this is for the further information of the Member for Tanglin - one of the abuses of the past was that the Planning Committee could just reject a plan without giving reasons. In the new Planning Committee, what we have tried to do is that, if we feel that reasons can be given, we ask the planners to call the architects and give them the reasons and ask them to make the necessary slight adjustments, so that their plans can come in and can be passed. Previously, what they tried to do was they just rejected and the architects or the contractors or the builders had to go and contact the right persons in order to get their plans passed. It is a pity though, Mr Speaker, that the persons who have scooted are not the real persons who are responsible for the corruption in the Planning Section of the S.I.T. The persons who are really corrupted in the Planning Section are still at large, and it will take some time before the people of Singapore can lay their hands on them. The Member for Farrer Park has sat on the Planning Committee, and I am sure he knows that if the members and the trustees who sat on the Committee did not agree with the planning experts, the planning experts could not just pass the plans. It was the planning experts who suggested passing or approving the plans, but it was left to the Planning Committee composed previously of a group of trustees who said "yes" or "no" to the plans, and they had been given powers to say "yes" or "no". Perhaps a Commission of Inquiry into the previous Planning Committee might reveal many matters of interest.

    Mr Speaker, when we started reorganising the S.I.T. in August this year, we sacked the corrupt expatriate officials, but at the same time we went one step further and replaced them with local architects and engineers. We have long-term and short-term plans: the long-term plans are not in detail but the short-term plans are. We have short-term plans to build low-cost housing. The old government only talked about low-cost housing. They had been talking about low-cost housing for four years. But, Mr Speaker, Sir, to pay $89 or $99 rent per month for a house is not

Column: 1186

low-cost housing. Neither is a one-room flat, the rental of which is $25 per month and which was subsidised on the eve of the elections just to get votes-low-cost housing. The old Government built a few thousand units in Kallang Estate just on the eve of the elections; but they, knowing the elections were coming, said, "O.K., we subsidise these flats. The rent is $60 each per month. Never mind, we subsidise $20." The total electorate will have to pay out the money eventually to subsidise these flats. We believe in building real low-cost housing without any hypocritical measures in hidden subsidies. Even about the so-called low-cost housing in Kallang Estate, when I went there yesterday, I received so many complaints in respect of the construction; the rain coming in during rainy days; the rent which the tenants cannot afford to pay.... When we say low-cost housing, we really mean low-cost housing - a one-room flat which we have started, and which we will rent out at less than $20 a month. We will not announce the details of the rentals until the houses are completed.

    At present there are 1,364 units of S.I.T. flats under construction. There are sites available on which we can build another 5,000 to 6,000 units straightaway. The plans are ready, most of the specifications are ready, and as soon as the Treasury are consulted, we will announce the plans publicly, and for these units, construction will start straightaway.

    The Member for Cairnhill asked just now when the Housing Authority is going to be created. Mr Speaker, the new Government not only works on form, but it also works on content. Not only are we proceeding with our plans to build low-cost housing for the poor and for those who cannot afford higher rent, but we are also proceeding very fast with the creation of a new Housing Authority which we hope in January next year will be accomplished.

    The Member for Farrer Park asked about the building cost at present. The present cost of building a one-room flat on the Kampong Tiong Bahru fire site, which does not include the price of land and roads, is $1,344.

Column: 1187



    The comparative figure in respect of a one-room flat at the old Kallang Airport is $2,986 - about double the price. The cost of building a two-room unit in Kampong Tiong Bahru is $2,206, and that in the Kallang Estate is $4,159. Mr Speaker, some people might query - perhaps the house will break down; it might have a beam without a ceiling; or it might have a ceiling without piling in the construction. But that is not the case. We have been able to get these low-cost houses because of many factors. One is that from now onwards, building contractors will not have to pay the usual percentage in order to get the housing contracts which may mean perhaps a saving of 20 per cent.

    The second factor is that our local architects have experience in building houses for local people. When I was in Kallang Estate yesterday, a woman complainant came to me and said, "The lavatory is broken." I asked her whether her husband was fat and she said that, on the contrary, he was as lean as myself. Then I said, "It must be that your husband squatted on the lavatory instead of sitting on it." Then she said, "Mr Ong, I am sorry. I am an Asian and I am not used to sitting. I am used to squatting on the lavatory." Mr Speaker, that is a clear example of European architects trying to build low-cost housing for local people; they do not understand low-cost housing.
